issue.title: Proxycommand fix

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
Simple fix of using unbuffered subprocess.PIPE uncovered a trickier bug
where the lack of timeout on initial readline call would pull data from
the first real packet, throwing off subsequent reads.

Doesn’t seem necessary to preserve a read buffer across recv() calls,
especially if it isn’t implemented correctly.

issue.title: sock._closed not set immediately - race condition when working with threads

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
I noticed a problem when using a transport in this fashion:
1. SSHClient() connection to server A
2. connection.get_transport()
3. transport.open_channel("direct-tcpip", ...)
4. SSHClient() connection to server B using channel from 3. as 'sock' parameter
5. work ...
6. close connection to B
7. close connection to A

During execution of this program I occasionally ( ~ 1/2 of times) get the following exception:
`File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/paramiko/client.py", line 394, in close 
    self._transport.close()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 645, in close 
    self.stop_thread()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 1550, in stop_thread
    and not self.sock._closed and not self.packetizer.closed
AttributeError: 'Channel' object has no attribute '_closed'
`
This might be due to not immediate change to socket._closed attribute when the socket is closed and than _closed is checked. When I assign `False` manually to this attribute seems to get rid of this problem. Something similar should be done at the declaration of 'sock' variable.

body: Spliced gateway support into Fabric 2 & confirmed this myself under Python 3. Fix inbound.

Turns out just updating `Channel` to expose both attributes was way more elegant than doing some hackneyed getattr stuff elsewhere. ![](http://i.somethingawful.com/forumsystem/emoticons/emot-toot.gif)

Hi, after installing 2.0.2, I'm still getting the same error when using ProxyCommand:

```
traceback (most recent call last):
  File "testing.py", line 16, in <module>
    ssh.close()
  File "/home/ngoldin/virtualenv/python3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paramiko/client.py", line 394, in close
    self._transport.close()
  File "/home/ngoldin/virtualenv/python3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 645, in close
    self.stop_thread()
  File "/home/ngoldin/virtualenv/python3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 1552, in stop_thread
    and not self.sock._closed and not self.packetizer.closed
AttributeError: 'ProxyCommand' object has no attribute '_closed'
Error in atexit._run_exitfuncs:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ngoldin/virtualenv/python3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 77, in _join_lingering_threads
    thr.stop_thread()
  File "/home/ngoldin/virtualenv/python3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paramiko/transport.py", line 1552, in stop_thread
    and not self.sock._closed and not self.packetizer.closed
AttributeError: 'ProxyCommand' object has no attribute '_closed'
```
Well that'd be because `ProxyCommand` isn't `Channel`, so it never got the fix. Bah! Thanks for the report. Will make a new ticket & fix that real quick

issue.title: ProxyCommand objects need the socket-like-obj _closed fix too
